isn't kind of a one template fits all and I guess if you really wanted to try
and come up with some kind of answer for this you could start with asking like okay what is machine learning well
Machine learning is the process of building something that learns from data that improves continuously as it sees
more and more data basically a machine learning model well then by extension from that definition you could say okay
well then a machine Learning System must be all of the support structure and all
of the chaotic processes and systems that you can develop around deploying training
evaluating and monitoring this software artifact that you get that learns from
data and then can make Addictions on data that it hasn't seen before so let's make this a bit more concrete
so suppose you are a data scientist and you are working for a cyber security company
and you've said okay well you know what malware is really difficult to detect with rules why don't we come up with a
machine learning model that can detect a malware from some statistical properties
so you start building you're working on your own you start building out this little system you have some storage
layer these are images that are specific to Google Cloud because that's the
platform that I'm most familiar but you can imagine this could be any generic storage layer in this storage layer you
have collected some samples of malware and some samples of normal programs then
you compute some features that you might think are useful for the model to learn
to distinguish between malware samples and normal computer programs you store them in some kind of data store
and then you come up with a little data pipeline so at this point when things are still very simple this data pipeline
can be something as simple as a sequence of Python scripts and all these scripts
do is they read from this data store they split the data into a training data
set so this is the set that you will be using to teach your model to distinguish between malicious and benign computer
programs and then a testing set and this is the set that you will use to check
how well the model has learned and obviously it's important for you to separate these because you want to check
that the model hasn't memorized the samples that you were showing it because then it would be useless when you put it
in production and so that's what the test set is for and then you have a number of other steps and you come up
with this little data pipeline so everything is still kind of simple and especially if you're the lone data
scientist in this fictional cyber security company you know you can probably get away with some Python
scripts and maybe a few Crown jobs and at the end of this process you produce a model and your manager says okay really cool
you have developed this model we want to put it live we have an upstream API
that's or an upstream service that's going to be sending collecting some
samples that people submit and we need your model to tell whether or not this
particular computer program is malicious so you wrap this model in a little API
and this is what we call live inference and then you wait for a requests to come in and you get a request for the model
to make a prediction and the model does its job so it says with very high probability this sample that was sent to
me is malicious and up until this point everything works fine
um but then things start to get a bit more complicated
so the one special thing perhaps that distinguishes machine Learning Systems
more than um from from normal software systems is that the inputs are not in your control
and what I mean by this is that what you get what kind of malware samples you get
can change very rapidly so today your motto is an expert on determining
whether or not something is malicious based on all of the data that you have collected up until day one but tomorrow
people may develop a new type of malware a new type of malware and now with all
of these automated exploit creation toolkits we know that we can get chat GPT to help us write
malware the rate at which these malicious samples change can be very fast so on day one your model might be
performing very well but then on day two when you get some new kinds of malware
samples that are sent to the model to make predictions it might not be so great anymore so you see this
probability number is starting to decline the model is becoming less and less confident at the at making
predictions because it is now seeing samples where the data of those samples
is very far or starting to get further and further from the distribution of the data on which the model was trained this
is something that we talk about a lot when building machine learning systems and we usually call it a data drift
so on day two things were getting worse but they are still kind of okay and then
you know on day three um as more as the malware samples that you're starting to see are kind of
drifting further and further apart from the training data on which the model was trained you're starting to see kind of
catastrophic degradation so by day three or maybe day four when you send the
malicious sample and try to have this model make a prediction all of a sudden the model thinks that this sample which
we know is malware um is is actually benign because the probability has has dipped quite low so
like at this point you would be already seeing catastrophic degradation of model performance
so this is one Challenge and to combat this you basically need to put in monitoring you need to keep tabs on what
this model is doing in production all the time to make sure that it doesn't drift too far away from what it's
supposed to be doing you need to make sure that if you are trying to predict whether or not something is malicious
that even X days after the model has been trained you're still having some kind of acceptable performance
and this is not always as simple of a problem as it sounds because obviously
in order to measure how well your model is performing you need data where you know the ground truth so in order to
compare the model's responses to the actual values you need to collect some
well-known data samples where someone else has done the labeling now with malware this is
still possible because we have a lot of malware repositories where researchers are submitting samples so we can kind of
take data from there and continuously test our model but with something like recommender systems you might not even
know kind of what the right answer is say we're trying to recommend music to to users or podcast users if a user
clicked on that podcast does it mean that they liked it does it mean that they you know were just viewing it
it can be hard to tell what is actually like ground truth in many cases which
makes this model monitoring quite hard in in some cases
now suppose you've noticed that okay your model has degraded so now you need to retrain a model

so basically this then you might also be faced with actually trying to determine

but the reality is much more complicated than that so imagine if you have this which is our

so kind of easily attached to just using some tool
or machine learning framework or open source product to to kind of fix our problems is that a

yeah there is there is Cool Tech that they're using and we might be using boring Tech but at
least to boring boring infrastructure will not wake you up in the middle of the night because of some configuration

has been kind of a principle the people have been talking about in the infra world for years is that infrastructure
should ultimately be boring it should be so boring that you don't even know it's there and it should definitely not have
unknown unknowns because those are the ones that are going to be waking you up at 2 am
at night because of some issue that you will then have to debug
and this is basically why just adding tools to your machine
Learning System is not necessarily a good recipe because for every cool piece of tech that you've seen Shopify using
you've seen Spotify using there are exponentially multiplying unknowns unknowns so these are failure modes that

not saddle ourselves with the complexity of scale until you actually reach that scale a lot of these systems used by big
tech companies are specifically developed to answer their needs and if you don't have a million active users

fancy Vector database because you're not hitting that scale so why why would you give yourself a headache of managing
something that is created for scale when you don't have that the hardest problem is not the tech so I
think this is a common theme that probably reverberates in in other parts of
software engineering but very commonly the hardest problem about building a platform is not the tech it's the fact
that there are kind of two engineering cultures in machine learning there is the data science side where people can
come from a variety of backgrounds from from Academia from industry from natural
science research and then there is the engineering part that mostly comes from
kind of a software development background and what I like about this blog post that was published by Google
is that they actually talk about how a German steel distributor cluckner
reinvented its data science workflows and they mentioned very many times during this blog post that the hardest
problems that they were facing were actually not so much the software tools
that they were using for their machine Learning System but it was that there was a really big gap between the devops
engineers that were in charge of deploying the machine learning model and the data scientists that were developing
this model and so some of the cultural kind of challenges that they mentioned was like
for example advocating for Version Control the devops engineers wanted everything to be in git the data
scientists were not so sure the data scientists wanted to maintain their own virtual machines to devops Engineers
thought that this was both a security and an infrastructure Nightmare and so Bridging the Gap between these two
cultures is one of the one of the problems that you can't solve just by
deploying some ml Ops tool to take it even further
these problems also exist even in big tech companies where you might think that there is a pretty strong drive to
have excellent engineering culture and this is another paper that was published by Google that attempts to create some
kind of framework for you to use to evaluate your production Readiness and there is an interesting point in this
paper that says that even though Google has a pretty rigorous engineering culture these tests that they suggest in
this paper were not implemented by more than 80 percent of teams and I thought
that this was a pretty interesting statistic given that we often think like well in places like Google there is a
pretty hardcore engineering culture so probably you know they don't have this problem of having a big gap between the
engineering side and the data science side but it turns out that even at places like Google this does seem to
be a problem another thing that kind of follows on from this is that automation is not
necessarily a silver bullet so as Engineers I guess one of our
professional hazards is that since we know how to program and we can write scripts and services whenever we see a
problem even if we have to perform it only once we really want to automate it
away and this kind of desire to automate things doesn't necessarily exist on the data science side where people are more
interested in doing experiments and kind of having the freedom to to Tinker
so when you're building a machine Learning System as an engineer your first instinct is to automate everything
just slap into ICD pipelines automated unit tests automated integration tests
but make everything work with a click of a button so that no one has to use their personal VMS or Scripts
now the thing about this lesson is that every layer of automation you add is great when it works so say you've
onboarded your machine Learning System to use GitHub actions it's great when it works but every extra layer of
automation you add is one extra layer you need to debug when it doesn't so now you say you've added GitHub actions to
your machine Learning System well when it works no one cares about it but the second that it breaks you realize that
you now have a dependency on something else so definitely yes you need to automate things where it makes sense but
you also need to be mindful that every extra layer of automation you add is something that someone will need to
debug when it eventually breaks down
um lesson five simple models exist only in theory so one of my favorite things about

well just take you know you have a simple pipeline just take the file that comes out of it upload it to our tool
and we'll do the versioning and you're staring at your SQL statement random Excel sheet file and Docker container
and you're thinking like well this my reality is like exists in a different Universe than than what this tool
suggests um yeah so something these tools are
developed for very specific models and sometimes reality where we have various
pressures such as pressures from the business to deliver things doesn't correspond to what the tool was meant to
do so this is perhaps a bit of a controversial one but lesson six is that
abstractions make you go fast and slow you down and so what I mean by this is
that in machine learning engineering and data science in 2023 were spoiled for
Choice when it comes to various high-level Frameworks and libraries that
we have to do for model training and all this boils down is that you get used to just saying okay model.train and then
ignoring everything else that has to happen under the hood for this model to actually train but if you think about it
there is actually a huge amount of complexity that goes on behind this API
call there can be data that is being loaded from a database into your python
process there might be API calls to create a pod on kubernetes there may be
all kinds of things and so we have developed these abstractions so that we can develop faster but then when we kind
of start hitting a scale and we need to debug why something isn't running fast
and these abstractions hurt us because we're used to just saying okay model.train and then we don't know why
it's so slow so there is a constant tension when you're developing these systems between
adding more abstractions and increasing the velocity at which data scientists
which the humans that are working in your ml system can work and the tension
between bringing things closer to the metal or to the data but making things slower to develop and you have to find
the suitable trade-off in for your particular case on how to kind of
balance this lesson seven is more of an observation but
another thing that makes machine Learning Systems hard in production is that your feedback loops can vary from
seconds to weeks now if you think about standard software engineering you usually can set up your developer Tools
in such a way that you can have almost instant feedback on how your code is doing so you can have unit tests
integration tests CI CD pipelines and there is a good chance that within five
minutes of you making a commit or opening a pull request on GitHub you
will know at least to a certain degree whether your tests have passed and you know whether your linting is okay and
and various things like that the problem is that in machine Learning Systems some of these feedback loops can
can take many hours for example if you make a commit you open a pull request
and you start a model training process well it can take anywhere from one hour
to 48 hours for the model to finish training and only then you'll find out if your change was good then if we take
it a bit further if we're thinking about monitoring it can be weeks between you actually making that commit into your
production repository and you finding out that your model say degrades really quickly in production so you have to try
and understand why if we're talking about a b testing it can even be months
between you making that change in production and you finding out that that something was not wrong so when you're
trying to design these systems you have to think how can I track this change across all of these different Cycles to
then if something goes wrong say at the a b testing stage to try and understand what were the changes that I made that
then caused this thing to go wrong okay lesson eight
um the various machine learning Frameworks that we have tend to encourage coupling with the underlying
infrastructure and what do I mean by this well if you recall before I
mentioned that when we're building models we often need data pipelines so these are basically just sequences of
steps that have to run in a sequence to do various Transformations on the data
to produce the final model well a lot of the Frameworks that we have in machine learning
have specific sdks which means that when you're specifying this model you have to
write your code in a very specific way so this is kind of a pseudocode or pseudo python code but basically what
this shows is that for every framework that you use you have to import a specific library and
that library is kind of tightly coupled on the underlying infrastructure that the pipeline will then be deployed on
now this is all fine and and okay if you're just specifying your pipeline once but say you are using airflow and
all of a sudden you know your Tech leadership tells you that well we don't want to use airflow anymore so we have
to migrate everything to vertex AI or or another service then now all of a sudden
you have these pipelines and you have this logic that is tightly coupled with
airflow and you can't just pick up and move you have to rewrite it
so that is a another problem is finding a way to develop your actual pipeline
machine learning logic in such a way that it's not too tightly coupled with
whatever framework you happen to be using it's not always of course possible but at least you should strive towards
it lesson nine different parts of your system will need different development
velocities now remember a few slides back we were talking about these two layers in our
machine Learning System so we have the production um pipelines that produce the models and
then we have the whole experimentation setup where data scientists are trying to develop new models or experimenting
with various parameters and so forth and so you have to account for the fact that in this experimentation layer you should
do everything you can to make sure that iteration velocity is high so that might
mean that you don't have CI CD pipelines at this level you don't have unit testing you expect that most of the code
that data scientists write at the experimentation stage will be thrown away at another Point whereas when you
move to the production layer you lower the iteration velocity because here the
consequences of making a mistake are of course much larger than if that happens at the experimentation level
so you have to design your system with this in mind that there will be different layers of the system where
people will need to iterate at different velocities and then finally
what is kind of the most important Gap to close if you want to be able to
quickly develop machine Learning Systems is this experimentation production Gap
so how do we make sure that the code that is developed in these Jupiter notebooks the models that are trained
here how do we make sure that they can go as quickly as possible into the

risks and difficulties associated with that so if you don't get this right if you
make it very hard for people to move their code from experimentation to production it might take weeks or even
